description: Squares in which removing a suitably chosen digit yields another square and this process can be continued until the digits are exhausted.
example: 1296 = 36^2 belongs to the sequence as removing 2 yields 196 = 14^2. Removing a 9 from 196 yields 16, removing 6 yields 1 and all are perfect squares.
author: _Amarnath Murthy_, Jun 27 2001
extensions: Corrected and extended by Larry Reeves (larryr(AT)acm.org), Jul 02 2001. Further terms from _Klaus Brockhaus_, Jul 05 2001
